title: Why did Metallica bury bass players in the mix, and still do to this day? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s part of the genre, really. With a few exceptions, most hard rock/metal bass lines are just a doubling of the guitar part, an octave lower. The bass is seen and heard as a bridge to the drums. It’s main job in many genre’s is to complement the guitar(s), not necessarily be an separate, independent voice. Additionally, modern listening habits are different than ‘back in the day.’ ‘Boom Boxes’ and hifi stereo’s, car stereo’s and other open air sytems were the norm, not headphones. (This was the early days of walkman, and before the Ipod, and other modern listening devices) The lower frequencies of the bass are often better FELT, than actually heard with just the ears alone. Most headphones don’t really replicate the effect of moving a lot of air and hitting you in the chest like a big proper full speaker system does.  Take an original mix from back then and play it moderately loud in your car. You will hear and feel the bass very differently than listening at polite cafe volumes.
